newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ share market rises to 2-1/2 year high.
newsitem.headline: NZ share market rises to 2-1/2 year high.

text.p: The New Zealand benchmark NZSE-40 share index on Friday rose 22.14 points, 1.01 percent, to 2,221.67, its highest point since March 1994.
JB Were broker John Cobb said the market had been powering ahead this week following the government's sale to a Fletcher Forests-Brierley Investments consortium of Forestry Corp.
Recent economic data such as a strong fall in retail sales indicated an easing of monetary policy was in the wind.
"That's all pointing towards an easing in interest rates which the market has been waiting for for a long time.
"Our market has been in a hiatus period for 12 or 18 months waiting for a reduction in rates," Cobb said.
He said the Australian budget this week was also seen as positive for bonds and equities.
Investors shrugged off a poll which showed the ruling conservative National Party support slipped three points to 34 percent.
"There are more factors than just the election pushing the market along," Cobb said. "Economic news, world markets are having a bigger impact currently."
He said offshore investors had viewed the Fletcher purchase very positively.
Telecom has run up strongly since its first quarter result last week. The market leader, which has a 25 percent weighting in the New Zealand market, rose eight cents to an all-time high of $6.90.
Fletcher Forests was up nine cents to $2.03 while fellow forestry stock and No.2 in the market, Carter Holt Harvey was up seven to $3.27.
